characters: MEDIUM TEN YEAR OLD MONROE WATCHES HIM IN AWE.
MONROE IN HIS ROOM ON THE PHONE WITH ZEKE
KIDS AT THE PARTY DANCING AND MAKING OUT

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Monroe. Mo looks up.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL HALLWAY
dialogues.text: A sea of students split in half as the officer leads Mo, handcuffed, down the hallway. He is a foot shorter than a of the other students.

dialogues.speaker: MO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I know it seems bad, and for anybody else it probably would be, it would be very bad. But Zeke said this might happen, and while this is the biggest jam he has ever gotten me into, it’s definitely not the first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATE KAUFMAN (16) watches TV on the couch, she is holding bowl of popcorn. Our narrator is her younger brother, Monroe.

dialogues.speaker: MO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I was ten when I met Zeke and immediately I knew, I didn’t care where he was going. I wanted to be along for the ride.  INT —- KAUFMAN HOUSE - KITCHEN - SAME TIME

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC FADES UP
dialogues.text: We see a pair of hands go into the freezer and pull out a bottle of vodka. These hands belong to ISAAC “ZEKE” PRESA As soon as the glasses of Vodka are poured he puts the bo under the water faucet and carefully refills the exact am of liquid that he took out. He is singing along with the music the whole time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zeke walks into the room holding the two drinks. He is seventeen with shaggy red hair. He sit’s down on the couc next to Kate. She takes the drink and studies it for a se then takes a sip, he smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Zeke was my sister’s boyfriend. I don’t know if they called themselves that though. I only ever saw him on Tuesday nights. That was my parents date night. For all I knew he had other girlfriends who baby-sat their brothers on Monday, Wednesday and Thursday. But what was I gonna do? Kate was a big girl. And I was not a big guy. Zeke and Kate start making out and we slowly pan up to th top of the stairs where a 10-year-old MO is watching them through the gaps in the railing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mo, Kate and Isaac are walking though the carnival. Mo ha giant cotton candy in his hand. Zeke rips off a chunk fro the top.

dialogues.speaker: MO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The doctor told my parents I was in the eighth percentile for my age group. The three of them sit in a row playing that game where yo shoot a water gun at a balloon and try to pop it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That means if you lined up a hundred random ten-year-olds, ninety two of them would be taller than me. Zeke lifts a hammer high in the air and brings it down ha on the high striker, the bell rings and the lights flash. ride operator hands Monroe a stuffed turtle.

dialogues.speaker: MO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Those other seven kids must live in Hawaii or something because I had yet to meet a ten year old smaller than me. A group of girls come up and flirt with Zeke, feeling his muscles and squeezing Monroe’s cheeks. Isaac picks up Mon and throws him over his shoulder spinning him around. The girls love it. Kate comes back with two hot dogs and pull Isaac away from the girls.

dialogues.speaker: MO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I knew he used me to hit on girls. Which should have made me mad... We see the three of them in line to ride a roller coaster is too short to get on. Zeke pulls the ride operator asid and speaks to him for a minute. We see Zeke and Mo sitting next to each other on the roll coaster, screaming with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three of them sit in the dark, the lights of the acti movie splashed across their faces. Isaac pulls two beers of his jacket. He gives one to Kate and cracks the other himself. Monroe looks at Isaac holding his drink. Isaac checks to see that Kate isn’t looking and let’s Mo take a of the beer. He grimaces at the taste and Zeke laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ..-But I didn’t really care because in my head I kept coming back to that row of a hundred 10-year-olds. And I'd think if you lined them all up in order from tallest to shortest-—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kate, Mo and their parents watch Zeke play in a big footb game. He has the ball and charges down the field, plowing through every player on his path to the end zone.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: -Zeke could beat the crap out of every one of them. The Kaufman family cheers for Zeke along with everybody e We watch from Kate’s POV as a cheerleader jumps into Zeke arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kate and Zeke are having an intense argument. Mo watches the top of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: MO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I couldn’t really blame her when she broke up with him. But he didn’t cheat on me so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zeke storms out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: Where are you going? Mo is barefoot in his pajamas. Zeke doesn’t even turn aro when he speaks, he just keeps moving towards the car. Mo chases after him.

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: Go back inside Mo.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Can I come with you?

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: No man. Your sister wouldn't like that.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Now you care what she would like? Zeke laughs at the quick wit of such a squeaky little voi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have things I have to do.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: I won’t get in the way, I swear. Just for tonight. Zeke looks at him for a second.

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: Alright fine, but I’m bringing you home in an hour. Mo walks around to the passenger side of the car.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: What are we going to do for an hour?

dialogues.speaker: AN EMPTY PARKING LOT
dialogues.text: MUSIC: Toots and the Maytals - Take me Home, Country Road SLOW MOTION: Zeke’s dark green 1978 Mercedes SLC 170 come spinning into view. The boys scream at the top of their lungs as the car does donuts all around the lot.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That hour lasted six years. The green mercedes spins to a stop. Monroe sits in the front seat he is 16 years old and scra as ever. In the driver’s seat Zeke is 23, he’s tall, hand and well built with dark hair and a goofy smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mo is sitting on an examination table, giving himself a s His parents and a doctor look on. Mo shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: You are getting good at that.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s wrong.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRI
dialogues.text: I think he is upset he isn’t as tall as he thought he would be.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: I thought I would get like...really tall.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (finding this amusing) No no, It won’t make you any taller than you were always meant to be, the shots just help to keep you growing at the same pace with your peers.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: But I’m not.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: I’m with Mo on this, I’m spending a fortune for these shots and he’s still... (he indicates Mo’s height with his hands)

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: You really don’t need to worry. Most patients with growth hormone deficiency's like this don’t start reaching potential until they are at least eighteen.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRI
dialogues.text: (looking at her watch) We need to get him back to school.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Okay let’s do this. When do you turn sixteen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next week.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: You get your license? Mo nods.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s meet again in six months, if you aren’t starting to make improvements, we can talk about other strategies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mo's parents pull up in front of the school, he get’s out

dialogues.speaker: SHERRI
dialogues.text: Don’t forget your lunch. He takes the lunch bag from her. We see Mo start to walk school as soon as his parents pull away he runs back out the parking lot. To a car parked on the other side. Zeke’s POV - Mo running towards his car. INT. ZEKE’S CAR - SECONDS LATER Zeke somehow manages to smoke a cigarette, drive the car, surf the radio, lecture about nothing, and stuff his face with half of Mo’s peanut butter and jelly sandwich. Mo quietly watches.

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: ...It’s like in King Kong when the monkey has got the chick in his hand and he is throwing her around. Yea, she is scared but she is also super turned on, because- this is what I am saying - girls like to be thrown around when you are having sex. They like somebody that’s going to pick them up and throw them up against a wall or on the bed. Because it makes them feel small, it makes them feel like you are a real man, but more importantly like they are this fragile little girl. (realizing his audience) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With you it will be different though. I don’t think there are many girls you can pick up. We’ll have to figure out your own thing. Shit where am I going again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mo and Zeke are with Zeke’s two friends, NICK AND TONY, watching a football game. Across from them, three pretty girls are at a different table watching the game, minding their own business. Zeke yells to the girls at the next table.

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: What is this? Junior High?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: Boys over here, girls over there, I feel like we are at an eighth grade dance or something. The girls laugh. ZEKE (CONT’D) (pointing at his friends) I'll trade you him and him. (pointing at the girls) For her and her.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: That one looks a little young. Mo blushes.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: He thinks you look a little old.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: BAR — MOMENTS LATER The guys and girls are all squeezed at one table screamin the game on TV. The older one is sitting on Mo’s lap. The friends share a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mo drives his car, alone for the first time. He looks aro the empty car feeling incredibly old. He turns on to a ne street and stops. He is double parked, listening to Bruce Springsteen and singing along with the music at the top of his lungs. Car pull up behind him and honk, he waves them to go around. Across the street Zeke comes out of his apartment buildin and jay walks across the street, pissing off the same driver's that are trying to get around Mo’s car. He hops and Mo pulls out.

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: I can’t believe it.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: I’m a real person now.

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: I didn’t think they gave driver's licenses to kids who couldn’t reach the pedals.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: I have to wear special shoes.

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: No fucking way. He tries to bend over and see.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: I'm kidding you idiot. I can reach the pedals.

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: Let me see the thing. Mo pulls out his wallet and shows him his license. ZEKE (CONT’D) (reading) Monroe Ernest Kaufman. God that’s unfortunate. (then) It is going to be so nice having a personal chauffeur.  10.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Get that idea out of your head right now. I am not driving you around.

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me? Do you know how many years of me driving your sorry ass around you have to make up for?

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: I’ve got an hour and a half until I have to be at school. Where do you want to go?

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: I thought your school started at

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Yeah but the first class is bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: I’m hungry. Zeke pulls out a joint from his shirt pocket and lights i

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Not in my new car man.

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: It’s weed, it smells good. It will compliment the new car smell. (He takes a puff) You should really smoke this, you might relax a little bit. (then) Don’t you have that research paper for your art class?

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Yeah, so?

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: Well let’s go look at some shit. (british) To the museum driver, show me the meaning of haste. INT —- CHICAGO INSTITUTE OF ART - DAY Zeke and Mo walk through the museum.  11.

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: So what's the assignment?

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: I’m supposed to pick a painting I think is important and write about it.

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: What about this one? Zeke points to a painting by Cy Twombly entitled “Leda an the Swan.”

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Looks like a bunch of scribbles and dicks on a blank canvas to me.

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: If you boiled life down to it’s essentials that’s probably all it would look like too. It’s just a bunch of disruptive gestures and violence and explosions...and dicks and liquids flying around in a void. Everything else is superfluous window dressing.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: There’s more to life than “liquids flying around” and dicks and violence.

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: Not really, you just think there is. But if you really want to represent what’s important, what’s constant, there it is in front of you in one immediate experience. If I asked you to make a picture of what’s important in life you’d probably show me an iPhone photo of your fucking Xbox.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: I could make this painting in like 5 minutes dude.

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, you and everyone’s kid right? First of all, no you can’t and the proof of that is that you didn’t. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Second of all the world doesn’t care about what you MIGHT be able to do if you really put your mind to it, the world only cares about what you actually did. Mo is left staring at the painting, Zeke continues on thr the exhibit.

dialogues.speaker: MO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A dick in space. That’s Zeke. He shouldn’t be here, he should be in college. EXT. ZEKE’S DAD'S HOUSE - FLASHBACK THREE YEARS A group of kids gathered around Zeke as he throws the las his luggage in the car. There is a University of Michigan flag in his back window. Some girls are crying. Mo is in back not saying much, but clearly sad to see his friend g Zeke waves one last goodbye and drives off. The crowd disperses, Mo is the last one staring down the empty stre

dialogues.speaker: MO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He went to the University of Michigan and was persuaded by some friends to pledge the fraternity Sigma Nu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zeke is stripped down to his underwear and blindfolded. A group of college seniors circle around him, taunting him. even pours his beer out on Zeke’s head.

dialogues.speaker: MO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I don’t know a lot about pledging fraternities, but apparently it is a very rigorous process, and Zeke soon realized it wasn’t for him. Zeke punches the senior standing in front of him, he nail him square in the face. Backing up, Zeke stumbles into another boy and finds the beer bottle in his hand. He gra it and smashes it over another boy’s head, blood starts pouring. At this point the surrounding boys descend on hi viciously.

dialogues.speaker: MO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The frat boys were really upset he didn’t want to keep pledging.  13. EXT. ZEKE’S DAD’S HOUSE - 2 WEEKS LATER Zeke’s car comes back down the same road it left only a f weeks earlier. This time there is no crowd of people in h driveway. Just Mo standing alone. Zeke get’s out of the c his face is black and blue.

dialogues.speaker: MO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: One of their dads was the dean and he got Zeke kicked out. It was all very political. INT. ZEKE’S DAD’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS Mo helps Zeke carry his bags back into the house. In the living room Zeke’s Dad is drunk and passed out in front o the television.

dialogues.speaker: MO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Zeke’s Dad seemed pretty cool about the whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mo gives the painting one last look and goes to catch up his friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mo walks into the school as the first period is ending. T hallway is completely empty. The bell rings and students in from everywhere around him. He is in a forest of kids he barely comes up their chests. He pushes through, miser and unnoticed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mo eats with his parents.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: How was the first day with the car?

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Really good.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: How was school?  14.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Good. (clearing his plate) I gotta go though.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: I was going to go over to Zeke’s.

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: It’s a school night.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: He is helping me with my homework.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRI
dialogues.text: That is so nice of him.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Yeah, he had a lot of these classes before so...

dialogues.speaker: REUBEN
dialogues.text: (not convinced) Doesn’t he have work tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: He quit his job.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRI
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: They were hiring people above him. He had to leave...It was all very political.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRI
dialogues.text: So what's he going to do now?

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: He’s still trying to figure that out. He said he wants to break into the art world.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Why doesn’t he come here and help you with your homework? We haven't seen him in ages.  INT. 15.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: (halfway out of the room) Come on, he’s doing me a favor. I can’t ask him to drive all the way over.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: Alright.

dialogues.speaker: SHERRI
dialogues.text: Well, tell him to come over and see us every once in a while. We miss him.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: And be careful in that car.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: DAD
dialogues.text: All it takes is ten seconds of stupid to ruin your whole life.

dialogues.speaker: MO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (gone) I know. ZEKE’S APARTMENT - LATER CLOSE UP - A quarter landing in a glass of brown liquid. Rack focus to the boys on the other side of the room.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: That’s never happened to me before.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Who has to drink that?

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: You do.  16.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: (devastated) What’s in it.

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: (blissful) Whiskey, vodka, Beer, red wine, Robitusin, Milk duds, Xanax, orange juice.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (still holding his eye) No, he’s going to die. I’1l drink it for him.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Like hell you will.

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: He can do it. He holds the glass up to his face. ZEKE (CONT’D) Wait I need music for this. Zeke goes over to the speakers and turns up the music. Mo closes his eyes and chugs the drink. ZEKE (CONT’D) (As Mo chugs) Okay, this is for Nick. What would you rather, every time somebody says your name you jiz in your pants OR every time you wake up in the morning Mo punches you as hard as he can in the face. Mo finishes the drink.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: But I would never do that.

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: It’s a fictional world. In this universe you would have no control over your body.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Can I change my name?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Momo punch me as hard you can in the arm right now. The boys laugh.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: It would be much more painful in your face- Woah I feel weird.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I know I just want to get a sense of what I’m working with.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: It would hurt, I promise. They look at him skeptically.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I‘1ll take getting punched by the kid.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Fuck you, let me punch you, let me show you what you’re in for.

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: Okay enough of this it’s my turn. Mo punches Nick right in the face. Everybody is stunned silent. Then Nick starts cracking up. ZEKE (CONT’D) What the hell are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: I don’t know I’m sorry. I wanted you to see I could punch.

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: Nick can he punch?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I’1l live.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Yeah but it hurt right. Mo collapses on the ground. FADE OUT.  18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All around him kids are socializing, gathered in little clumps around the room. He sits alone at his desk with a terrible hangover. MO’S POV - SOPHIE WILLITS sitting on her desk, talking to group of her girlfriends. She looks over to Monroe, he sm and then looks away quickly. A boy, JON EPSTEIN, comes up to Mo’s desk.

dialogues.speaker: EPSTEIN
dialogues.text: Monroe, what’s up man?

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Hey Epstein.

dialogues.speaker: EPSTEIN
dialogues.text: How do you always get away with skipping first period? It’s incredible.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Mo just wants to look at Sophie in peace.

dialogues.speaker: EPSTEIN
dialogues.text: I’m serious, every time I skip a class I have so many people crawling up my ass.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: I don’t know- My friend told me once, if they don’t notice you when you're there, they won’t notice when you aren’t.

dialogues.speaker: EPSTEIN
dialogues.text: You’re a legend. Mo shrugs at the compliment.

dialogues.speaker: EPSTEIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: I’m a little hungover.

dialogues.speaker: EPSTEIN
dialogues.text: But it’s Wednesday. Mo shrugs again.  19.

dialogues.speaker: EPSTEIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Incredible. Mo goes back to staring at Sophie. Epstein follows Mo’s eyeline across the room.

dialogues.speaker: EPSTEIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sophie Willits?

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: What? No?

dialogues.speaker: EPSTEIN
dialogues.text: Hey hey, don’t get defensive. She is hot. Ya know what... (moving in closer and whispering) Paul’s parents are going out of town this weekend and we are throwing a rager at his house. Guarantee Sophie will be there.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: EPSTEIN
dialogues.text: What you think I’m lying?

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Did Paul say I could come?

dialogues.speaker: EPSTEIN
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about Paul. I can invite anybody I want. I have carte blanche.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Okay cool, yeah I’1l come. Sophie looks back over at Mo and smiles. Epstein sees thi exchange.

dialogues.speaker: EPSTEIN
dialogues.text: Oh my god it’s so fucking on. Epstein goes back to his desk but remembers something.

dialogues.speaker: EPSTEIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s a pimps and ho’s party.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys dress like pimps girls dress like Hos.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: What does a pimp wear?

dialogues.speaker: EPSTEIN
dialogues.text: I don’t know, robes and chains and shit.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Alright cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mo is at Baseball practice. He is standing at the plate. swings hard but misses every time, striking out. He walks away from the plate defeated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mo is in the back changing out of his baseball gear. A fe the bigger, more senior players are gathered around nearb The ringleaders seem to be DANNY AND JOSH. Mo can’t help overhear they are talking about Paul's party.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Hey are you guys talking about Paul’s party?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (caught off guard) What? No- It’s just, it’s like a birthday thing.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: It’s going to be super low key. Just like some close friends and stuff.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: No, it’s cool, Epstein invited me.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Oh really?

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Yeah, Pimps and Ho’s party right?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Epstein invited you?  21. Mo packs his stuff up and heads out.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: Yup. See you there. The boys shrug at each other, confused at what just happe

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Epstein is going rogue.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Seriously. INT. ZEKE’S APARTMENT - NIGHT CLOSE UP - fighter jets flying through the air. Widen to reveal the boys are watching Top Gun.

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: What do you mean? Your parents love me.

dialogues.speaker: MO
dialogues.text: I know they do. You just have to go over there and re-up the charm. Just a little face time every few months to keep them happy. You put on a nice shirt. Maybe watch a little football with my Dad. And they’re off my case.
